üîµ¬†Python Decorators
Learn how Python decorators really work by watching us build one from scratch‚Äîstarting with a simple timing wrapper and gradually extending it to handle arguments, keyword arguments, and return values. By the end, you‚Äôll understand how decorators let you add powerful features to functions without changing their original code, making your programs cleaner, more flexible, and easier to reuse.

snippet.title: Matplotlib (Python Library) - Visually Explained
snippet.description:
üîµ Example code: https://rebrand.ly/kg1qk17

üîµ Chapters
00:00 - Intro to Matplotlib
00:29 - Install Matplotlib
00:35 - Import pyplot module
00:54 - Plot data
01:16 - Change x-axis values
01:34 - Add title and axis labels
02:18 - Add data point markers
02:43 - Add horizontal line
03:11 - Use colors / line styles
03:43 - Add a legend
04:15 - Use dot notation

üîµ Matplotlib
In this video, you will learn how to visualize data in Python using Matplotlib. Formatting options discussed in the video:

1. plt.plot()  
  - marker: Shape of the data points (e.g., "o", "s", "^", "*").  
  - label: Legend label for the data series (e.g., "Sunny days").  
  - color: Customize the line color (e.g., "blue", "green").  
2. plt.title()  
  - Title text (e.g., "Sunny days").  
  - Font size: fontsize=14 or any desired value.  
  - Font style: Use fontweight (e.g., "bold", "light").
3. plt.xlabel() & plt.ylabel()  
  - Label text (e.g., "Months", "Sunny days").  
  - Font size: fontsize=12 or your preferred size.  
4. plt.axhline()
  - y: The y-coordinate value for the line (e.g., avg_sunny_days).  
  - linestyle: Customize line style (e.g., "--", "-.", ":").  
  - color: Customize line color (e.g., "orange", "red", "gray").  
  - label: Legend label for the line (e.g., "Average").
5. plt.legend()
  - Location: Specify where the legend appears (e.g., "upper right", "lower left", "best").  
  - Font size: fontsize=10 or your preferred size.  


#Python  #CodingTips #PythonTutorial #LearnPython #PythonProgramming #CodingForBeginners #ProgrammingTips
tags: intro to data visualization in python

Whether you‚Äôre a beginner or brushing up on fundamentals, this guide is perfect for mastering Python variables.

00:35 Add Progress Bar with tqdm  
00:52 tqdm Info Breakdown

üîµ How to Add Progress Bars in Python Using tqdm | Improve Your Code Execution Feedback

In this video, you will learn how to add Python progress bars using the powerful tqdm library to visually track the progress of your loops and long-running tasks. Whether you‚Äôre debugging or just want a cleaner way to see task completion, progress bars are a must-have tool for your coding arsenal.

What You'll Learn:
1. Why Progress Bars Are Essential: Get immediate visual feedback during execution.
2. Customizing Progress Bars: Use desc, bar_format, and other options to make it yours.
3. Dynamic Colors in Jupyter Notebooks: Learn how tqdm.notebook enhances visual feedback.

#Python #ProgressBar #tqdm #CodingTips #PythonTutorial #LearnPython #PythonProgramming #CodingForBeginners #ProgrammingTips
